title: How practical or impractical is it when 'willing suspension of disbelief' is employed in situations of real life? - Quora

response.answer_text: How practical or impractical is it when 'willing suspension of disbelief' is employed in situations of real life? Not practical at all. I would say: not impractical either, because the term’s not applicable to real life. It applies to fiction, for fictional elements we’d disbelieve in real life - but for our enjoyment of the fiction, we prefer to suspend that disbelief.  “Willing suspension of disbelief” describes an approach to experiencing something you know to be a fiction account. Film, book, tv show, play, whatever. You know absolutely know beyond doubt: This is not happening. This is not real. It’s pretend. Willing suspension of disbelief is used in a case where we know it’s pretend, and we pretend it isn’t. Just for a better, more seamless enjoyment. You engage willing suspension of disbelief when you let go and immerse in the story. In the story’s theory and rules. You accept certain things that may be a bit implausible for real life. For the story, it’s just part of the package deal on offer. These unbelievable elements are established parts of the established story. Jet-packs and scum-ray blasters. Magic staves that make vwoo-vwoo noises when waved, and can conjure crap special effects at an arcane SHOUT. Three hundred feet monsters. I don’t mean that tall - these things have three hundred feet each. Human feet, looks like. Attached to a weird golf-ball body, with a staring eye in each dimple! Point is. You accept what’s presented as part of the story’s world and rules. This only gives the storymaker so much latitude. We’ll accept the different rules of the world, but if characters presented as human, and in particular, as reasonably intelligent keep making stupid and impossible-to-believe decisions just to keep the plot going - that’s not covered. That’s nothing to do with the rules of that reality. It’s just crap writing. Poor storytelling. It busts suspension of disbelief. It breaks deals with the audience. It takes them out of the story.  Point is. The term was invented to describe a specific thing about appreciating fiction. What the term means does not have applicability to real life. We are not in a position of first, knowing beyond doubt: this isn’t happening. This is not real. And then saying “hoo hoo, accept it anyway for fun! Dive on in. Let go.” If that happened in real life it wouldn’t be real life. Just an impromptu bit of fake-ass live-action role playing you decided to put on. Knock yourself out, but that’s not willing suspension of disbelief, so much as it is deliberately being an ass. The fact what you’re immersing in is not in reality happening is the fundamental condition of the term “willing suspension of disbelief.” It’s what the term means. In real life, it is actually happening. There’s no “disbelief” to suspend, in anything like the same sense. Everything that happens is real. Real people and things in motion, saying one thing, doing another - it is all really happening. We don’t have to suspend disbelief of fictional elements when there are none.  However, for real life we do have two other excellent terms. Perhaps you’re thinking of one of these? They’re not the same thing, but at least they would not be torturously misapplied: “benefit of doubt.” Here’s where you don’t know the truth of it. You may have some idea, but you don’t know. You suspect, but you don’t know. You’re poised between believing the worst (probably of someone) or just…believing the worst isn’t true. And you cut someone a break. You don’t know they’re innocent, but you decide you’ll take the risk and act as if. You give them the benefit of your doubt in the matter.“suspension of judgment.” Nothing like “suspension of disbelief.” Nothing like “benefit of doubt.” Here is skeptic inquiry: rejection of final conclusion. Provisional conclusions only, with a purpose to act and test. You do not decide the truth. You do not believe. You do not disbelieve. You suspend judgment, pending compelling demonstration.That first one can be risky, but not so risky as trying to live without it. The second one…you would not believe the difference it can make in every facet of life.

Having the ability to suspend disbelief for a limited time in order to hear someone out, research something more intensively, keep an open, but not gullible, mind, and avoid the pitfalls of blinding cynicism, can be a very practical approach when endeavoring to get at the truth. Any kind of obstacle to potential truth that can be removed at least temporarily can only be helpful in most situations, except perhaps, for those situations which require immediate emergency action with no time to investigate the veracity of what one is seeing/hearing. Those are the times when we have to be able to trust and depend on our intuition, instincts, and gut feeling. Can you trust and depend on yours?

I don't think it's practical at all. When you suspend your disbelief, it's to enjoy the story unfolding. In real life, if there's a problem and some aspect is unrealistic, how will you solve the problem? You have nothing to lead you down a reliable trail of answers.

This depends on how far you have come with your consciousness. Belief (being second hand interpretations) take you so far, but when beliefs are not enough, and the urge to “know” becomes greater, it is easier, and necessary to suspend beliefs or disbeliefs.
Real life? Two people can observe the same object and yet describe it differently. Then they will disbelieve the others interpretation. Life? Life is only a reaction to an action. Can we see life?
It is practical as a factor, not as a fact.
